item.title: Pheromone
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Pheromone

Common name None

Chemical signals produced and emitted by living organisms and involved in intraspecific communication. They are usually composed of blends of allelochemicals; some may be sequestered from host plants, others are derivatives of plant components and yet others are produced de novo in the pheromone gland of the organism. The repertoire of responses elicited by pheromones is very extensive. For example, sex pheromones are produced by individuals of one sex (in most cases the females) and influence the seeking and mating behavior of the opposite sex. They are exploited in plant protection in the context of IPM. Aggregation pheromones attract both sexes. Pheromones may mark trails or oviposition sites, serve for kin recognition and elicit defensive maneuvers or aggressive behavior.

For a detailed treatment of pheromones, see the website listed below.

item.title: Phytoplasma
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Phytoplasma

Over the course of the previous century pathogens causing “yellows” diseases were variously known as viruses, mycoplasma-like organisms (MLOs) and finally phytoplasmas. They have not yet been cultured in artificial media, which has greatly hindered research. However, they have been identified by several means, including antibodies, DNA probes and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) primers. A proposed classification scheme distinguishes phytoplasma clades at the level of genera, and subclades as species. Of the 14 phytoplasma groups, a number have been named in the genus Candidatus.

The symptoms of “yellows” diseases vary, depending on the host plant. Plant growth may be stunted or dwarfed, due to reduced shoot growth and lack of apical dominance. Leaves tend to be yellow, although they may also turn reddish, are smaller than normal, and often curl inwards. There may also be a proliferation of leaves known as witches’ broom, or production of “asparagus fern” branching. Symptoms often appear to be hormonally induced.

While phytoplasmas can be transmitted by cuttings, grafting, and parasitic plants such as dodder (Cuscuta pentagona), they are primarily spread by insects, mainly Hemiptera. Leafhoppers (Cicadelloidea) and planthoppers (Fulgoroidea) are the predominant transmitters of phytoplasmas, although Psyllidae and a member of the Flatidae are also known vectors.

Several traits combine to make these hemimetabolous insects efficient vectors of phytoplasmas. Their nymphs and adults feed on the same hosts and inhabit the same physical location, thus facilitate transmission by juveniles as well adults. They feed selectively on the tissues wherein phytoplasmas reside, namely phloem sieve elements. The insects’ feeding is non-destructive, promoting successful inoculation of the vascular system, without damaging the plant. Finally, the phytoplasmas replicate in the insect hosts and persist therein, and can therefore be transmitted for days, weeks or months after the initial acquisition.

The transmission cycle of phytoplasmas can be divided into two phases. 1. The acquisition time or the acquisition access period (AAP), the length of time an insect must feed on the plant in order to acquire the phytoplasma. Most insects require more than 24 hours for maximum acquisition and subsequent transmission of the pathogen. This period is age dependent (nymphs versus adults) and has to be established for each individual species. 2. The latent period (LP), the time required by the phytoplasma to penetrate the gut wall, migrate to the salivary glands, replicate and become transmissible. This period is temperature dependent. At optimal temperatures it can be as short as 10-20 days, whereas at low temperatures 50-60 days may be required. At high temperatures (relative to the particular phytoplasma, usually above 30°C), phytoplasmas are inactivated within the insect.

Relationships between vector and phytoplasmas are highly complex. Vectors can have dual infections; they may harbor a phytoplasma but be unable to vector it to healthy plants; or they may be unable to acquire a given phytoplasma from one plant species, but obtain it from another plant. Polyphagous vectors, such as Macrosteles fascifrons (Stål) (Cicadellidae), are capable to infecting a range of plants with a number of phytoplasmas, whereas monophagous or oligophagous vectors, such as Scaphoideus luteolus DeLong (Cicadellidae), can transmit phytoplasmas only to a few plant species, primarily Ulmus spp.

item.title: Phytoseiidae
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Phytoseiidae

Taxonomic placing: Acari, Parasitiformes, Mesostigmata.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: World-wide, with more than 1,700 described species.

Economic importance: This family contains several important natural enemies of plant pests, especially spider mites (Tetranychidae), false spider mites (Tenuipalpidae), rust and gall mites (Eriophyidae) and thrips (Thysanoptera). The Phytoseiidae are therefore very important in the biological control (whether natural or humanly-instigated) of such pests.

Morphology: Phytoseiids bear an entire dorsal plate with less than 23 pairs of setae. The stigmata open between legs III and IV and the metasternal plates are small. The legs are undifferentiated, usually with two claws and an empodium, and the digits of the male spermadactyls are distally free.

Life cycle: Phytoseiids, fast-moving, proactive predators, live on plants and in the upper soil layers. They mostly attack mites, but also small insects, nematodes and fungi, and may feed on plants, including pollen and extrafloral nectaries. Most species develop within a week at 27°C and 60-90% relative humidity and usually deposit 30-40 eggs per female. Sex determination in most phytoseiids is by parahaploidy (a few species are thelytokous) and the sex ratio in the field is around 0.75. The males locate females by a pheromone. Phytoseiids survive winters either by going into a facultative reproductive diapause (induced by a short daylight and low temperatures) or by being resistant to low temperatures.

Phytoseiids disperse by running on leaves, walking along spider mite webs, crawling on the soil and while borne on air streams. Dispersal by winds is due to prey depletion; the mites (mostly young, mated females) moving onto exposed surfaces and placing themselves in a position to be lifted by air currents. Once on plants the predators are attracted to their prey by volatiles emitted by the pest-damaged foliage as well as to spider mite cues, such as webbing and other residues.

Biological control-oriented studies on the Phytoseiidae began only at the close of the Second World War, when outbreaks of spider mites that followed the introduction of synthetic pesticides on commercial crops indicated the paramount importance of these predators. The ability of Phytoseiidae to develop resistance to pesticides contributed to their continuing use in biological control and integrated pest management (IPM) projects.

The diversity of feeding habits and life history traits of the Phytoseiidae indicated placing them in four categories, a grouping that could be used when selecting these predators for specific biological control purposes. Type I consists only of Phytoseiulus persimilis Athias-Henriot and its cogeners, all specialized predators of heavily-webbing spider mites, mostly Tetranychus spp. Type II phytoseiids feed on spider mites, but are not restricted to Tetranychus spp, devouring also spider mites that produce little webbing [e.g. the European red mite, Panonychus ulmi (Koch)], as well as other small mites and pollen. Type III species are generalists that often prefer prey other than spider mites (e.g. tarsonemids and thrips). Type IV phytoseiids are generalists that develop and reproduce best on pollen, with whose availability their population trends seem to be closely associated.

Phytoseiidae included in this compendium

Typhlodromus athiasae Porath and Swirski

Phytoseiulus persimilis Athias-Henriot
